awd_titl_txt: Scales of pH variability on Pacific coral reefs reconstructed from skeletal boron and boron isotopes
awd_abstract_narration:
The decreased vitality of coral reef ecosystems is often cited as one of the most prominent costs associated with the progressive oceanic uptake of fossil fuel carbon dioxide and the consequent ocean acidification. Yet, despite the prominent concerns, it is presently unknown whether and how regional oceanographically-induced pH variability is actually manifested at the site of coral calcification. This uncertainty requires comprehensive monitoring of diverse reef systems.  As a complementary approach to in situ monitoring installations, a research team from the Scripps Institution of Oceanography will make use of the known changes in Pacific ocean/atmosphere variability of the late 20th century as a retrospective monitoring system. In effect, the system of measurements from this targeted network of coral samples will provide a direct comparison to hindcast expectations of the pH variability forced by oceanographic change. These results of this project will allow a direct assessment of the extent to which massive corals in various oceanographic settings were actually sensitive to historical changes in regional pH. The project will serve as the doctoral research of a student who broadens participation of severely underrepresented groups. The project will also be used as a platform for public outreach through SIO Birch Aquarium exhibits. 

The research team will measure coral skeletal chemistry in existing coral cores from locations that represent very different geographic poles of historical Pacific basin-wide changes. Specifically, they will apply the boron isotopic proxy for pH, in conjunction with a suite of other skeletal tracers that might be sensitive to perturbations in seawater carbon chemistry, to generate seasonally-resolved records of environmental changes. Two of the study sites, Palmyra and Moorea, feature on going, multi-year in situ pH sensor installations. Accordingly, the research team will collect and analyze the most recent coral growth at these locations, which will provide the best available means for field calibration of the skeletal proxies. In general, the assessment of the scale of pH variability manifested at the site of calcification--and, especially, its relationship with oceanographic perturbations--is essential for establishing the proper perspective for projections of future anthropogenic effects on reef carbon chemistry.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The dual stresss of progressive heating and acidification of the ocean constitutes the primary threat to the vitality of coral reef ecosystems. Our objective in this project was to collect and analyse the chemistry of coral skeletons from regions subject to natural oceanographic change on seasonal, innterannual and decadal change. The chemical tracers in the coral skeletons provide an in situ retrospective monitoring system that allows assessment of the coral response to large perturbations in heat and acidification stress, and in particular, the incorporation of boron and its isotopic composition is known to be pH dependent. Thus we concentrated on boron and its isotopic concentration in a collection of new and existing coral skeletal samples. For the new coral material, as part of this project, we collected 4 separate cores from Palymyra Island coral colonies that were growing immediately adjacent to in situ sensor packages that have been deployed since 2010 to measure pH, temperature and oxygen. The coral cores span the growth years of 1995-2016, therefore allowing the direct comparison between the coral response over two extreme El Ni?o events (1997/98 and 2015-2016).  The comparison between the coral skeleton boron and the pH sensor output demonstrates convincingly that the corals elevate the pH of their calcifying fluid with respect to ambient pH, but to varying extent among and within colonies.  Furthermore we found excursions in the boron isotopic composition over the skeletal growth year 2015-2016 that suggest sporadic diminution of the capacity to elevate calcifying fluid pH, coincident with the intervals of maximal heat stress associated with the maturation of the strong El Ni?o event.  No such excursions were observed for the coral growth year of 1997-1998. Thus, though it is clear that the boron isotopic composition of corals cannot be used as a strict proxy for ambient seawater pH variability (because of the strong physiological control over the pH of the calcifying fluid), the skeletal boron isotopic composition is likely a sensitive indicator of the stress to the coral calification process. Meanwhile, we document clear patterns of the trace element incorporation in a wide suite of coral samples  that yield strong clues to the coral calcification process. For instance, the incorporation of boron and uranium varies significantly across colonies of the same reef (Palmyra), but is highly correlated with the ratio of lithium to magnesium in the same samples. And these intercolony differences are in turn correlated with carbon isotopic composition dfferences among colonies. A fully consistent pattern of trace element and isotopic behavior plays out over decadal timescales in eastern Pacific coral samples. Thus, the full set of trace element analyses that we have made as part of this project can be used to constrain physiological models of coral calcification--an essential step to understanding the vulnerabilities to various stresses, both natural and anthropogenic.

Broader Impacts:  This project supported the education, laboratory training, field training, and, ultimately, the successful PhD dissertation of Sara Sanchez, a member of a severely under-represented group in the STEM fields. This project also provided the principal foundation for now-sustained international collaboration between laboratories in the U.S., U.K. and Germany.
